Webinar Overview
In todayâ€™s world, data is everywhereâ€”but data alone doesnâ€™t drive decisions. Itâ€™s
Communicating data through clear, purposeful, and accessible visualizations is an essential skill for anyone working with dataâ€”whether youâ€™re a scientist, analyst, researcher, or manager. When well-crafted, the insights we extract and how clearly we communicate them that truly make an impact. However, poor design choices can hinder understanding or, worse, mislead the audienceâ€”intentionally or not.

Is this course for me?
This course is ideal for you if you:

want to master the art of presenting data through clear, impactful visualizations;
are looking to enhance your design skills to create visuals that are both effective and informative; and
are ready to invest time in selecting the right chart types, color schemes, fonts, and other elements that guide your audience and amplify your message.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Let me tell you about Amina.
She worked in customer retention at a mid-sized logistics company. Every Monday, her inbox was flooded with CSV filesâ€”customer complaints, delivery delays, package weights, region-wise returnsâ€¦
All of it collected diligently by the operations team.
But something was wrong.
Despite the data, customer churn kept rising. Leadership was frustrated. Amina felt helpless.
Until one day, she decided to stop sending spreadsheets and start telling stories with the data.

title: Prerequisites
text: Last updated: May 16th, 2025

title: Prerequisites
text:
Prior knowledge
We do not assume any prior knowledge of R pacakge development, but basic knowledge of R is expected. In particular, participants should be confident writing functions. Some experience with RStudio is beneficial.

title: Prerequisites
text:
R and RStudio
Please ensure that you have the latest versions of R and RStudio installed prior to the first session. Currently, thatâ€™s R-4.5.0 and RStudio-2025.05.0.
We also strongly recommend all participants to install the development tools to avoid potential issues installing packages.

Installing R
Download the pre-compiled binary for your OS from https://cloud.r-project.org/ and install. More specifically:
For Windows
Click â€œDownload R for Windowsâ€, then â€œbaseâ€, then â€œDownload R-4.5.0 for Windowsâ€. This will download an .exe file; once downloaded, open to start the installation.
For Mac
Click â€œDownload R for macOSâ€, then â€œR-4.5.0-arm64.pkgâ€ (the first option) to download the installer for Macs with Apple Silicon chips or â€œR-4.5.0-x86_64.pkgâ€ (the second option) to download the installer for Macs with Intel chips. Run the installer to complete installation.
For Linux
Click â€œDownload R for Linuxâ€. Instructions on installing are given for Debian, Fedora, Redhat, Suse and Ubuntu distributions. Where there is a choice, install both r-base and r-base-dev.


Installing R Studio Desktop (Open Source Edition)
Downloads are available from https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Download the relevant installer either under the â€œInstall RStudioâ€ header or, scrolling down the page, from the â€˜All installers and Tarballsâ€™ section. Run the installer to complete installation.
For Windows with no admin rights
Download the .zip source archive under â€œZip/Tarballsâ€. Extract the files to a folder where you have write access, e.g.Â C:\Users\username\RStudio. In this folder, open the bin directory and find the RStudio program: it is named rstudio.exe, but the file extension will typically be hidden, so look for rstudio. Right-click this executable to create a desktop shortcut. Double-click the executable or use the shortcut to open.
For all other operating systems
Download the relevant installer for your OS listed under â€œInstallers for Supported Platformsâ€. Run the installer to complete installation.


Development Tools
Some additional tools may be required to compile R packages from source.
For Windows with no admin rights
Download the latest (recommended) Rtools installer, Rtools.exe, from https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/Rtools/. Run the installer keeping the default settings.
For Windows with admin rights
Download the latest Rtools installer, Rtools.exe, from https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/Rtools/. Run the installer making the following selections: keep the default settings for the installation location and components to install; check the box to add rtools to the system PATH.
For Mac
Install XCode. Either:

Download and install XCode from the Mac AppStore: http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/xcode/id497799835?mt=12

Or for a smaller download size:

Register as an Apple Developer (free) here: https://developer.apple.com/programs/enroll/
Download the Command Line Tools for XCode appropriate for the version of OS X you are running from here: https://developer.apple.com/downloads/

For Linux
If you installed r-base-dev, when installing R, you should have all you need to build packages from source. Otherwise return to the instructions for installing R for your distribution and follow the instructions there to install the additional tools.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
R packages
Thank you to developers, sharers, teachers, and the entire R community for building things and creating resources to help us all learn.

tidyverse: Wickham et al., (2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software, 4(43), 1686, https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686
ggplot2: H. Wickham. ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. Springer-Verlag New York, 2016.
ggrepel: Kamil Slowikowski (2021). ggrepel: Automatically Position Non-Overlapping Text Labels with â€˜ggplot2â€™. R package version 0.9.1. https://github.com/slowkow/ggrepel
gghighlight: Hiroaki Yutani (2020). gghighlight: Highlight Lines and Points in â€˜ggplot2â€™. R package version 0.3.1. https://github.com/yutannihilation/gghighlight/
R Markdown: Yihui Xie and J.J. Allaire and Garrett Grolemund (2018). R Markdown: The Definitive Guide. Chapman and Hall/CRC. ISBN 9781138359338. URL https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown.
sf: Pebesma, E., 2018. Simple Features for R: Standardized Support for Spatial Vector Data. The R Journal 10 (1), 439-446, https://doi.org/10.32614/RJ-2018-009
paletteer: See AUTHORS file. (2021). paletteer: Comprehensive Collection of Color Palettes. R package version 1.3.0. https://github.com/EmilHvitfeldt/paletteer
gapminder: Jennifer Bryan (2017). gapminder: Data from Gapminder. https://github.com/jennybc/gapminder, http://www.gapminder.org/data/, https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.594018.
janitor:Sam Firke (2021). janitor: Simple Tools for Examining and Cleaning Dirty Data. R package version 2.1.0. https://github.com/sfirke/janitor

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
What is Data?

Data refers to raw facts, figures, and statistics that are collected through observation, measurement, research, or experimentation. On their own, data have no meaning until they are organized, analyzed, and interpreted.

Key Characteristics of Data:


Raw: Unprocessed and unorganized
Factual: Based on real-world events, measurements, or records

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Data Types Contd.
Numerical or Quantitative Data










Continuous Data
Discrete Data




Data that can take any value within a range.
Data that can take only specific, separate values.


Usually measured (can include decimals/fractions).
Usually countable (no decimals)


Examples:

Height of a person (e.g., 1.75 meters)
Temperature (e.g., 36.6Â°C)
Sales revenue (e.g., â‚¦1,254,500.75)

Examples:

Number of employees in a company (e.g., 15, 23, 50)
Number of students in a classroom
Number of cars sold in a day

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Data Types Contd.
Key Features of Numerical Data:


Can be compared, ordered, added, or averaged
Suitable for mathematical and statistical analysis
Often visualized using bar charts, histograms, line graphs, or scatter plots

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Data Types Contd.
Categorical or Qualitative Data

Categorical (or Qualitative) data refers to data that describes qualities or characteristics. Instead of numbers, it uses labels, names, or categories to represent information.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Data Types Contd.
Key Feature of Categorical Data:


Descriptive rather than numerical
Used to classify or group data
Cannot be meaningfully added, subtracted, or averaged
Can be visualized using bar charts, pie charts, or tables

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Mind the Gap
Problem: Data is abundant, but insights are scarce.
Solution: Visualization bridges the gap between raw data and strategic action.
Outcome: Simplifies storytelling and supports real-time decisions.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
COVID-19
COVID-19 dashboards helped governments track and respond to infection spikes and vaccinations.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Walmart Hurricane Forecasting

Context: We canâ€™t control the weather, yet it affects everything we do. Most days are calm, but when Mother Nature shows her power, normal life is turned upside down.
In these moments, how can businesses keep operating and support communities?
In 2004 as Hurricane Frances roared through the Caribbean toward Florida, Walmartâ€™s team asked themselves â€” how can we prepare smarter? Which products will people desperately need?
Walmart used historical sales data to anticipate what people would need most.
Insight: While obvious necessities like bottled water, flashlights, and batteries were expected, the data revealed a surprising pattern: strawberry Popâ€‘Tarts sales increased sevenfold, and beer became the top-selling item
Action Taken: Walmart stocked these items in bulk at regional distribution centers in the hurricane path.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Insights
The year-over-year analysis shows that while many stores maintained or improved sales, Store 16 â€” a consistent top performer â€” experienced a noticeable decline in 2014. This highlights how even successful locations can face unexpected dips, emphasizing the need for continuous monitoring and agile decision-making powered by data visualization.

section: Choosing the appropriate graph(s) for the data

Choosing the appropriate graph(s) for the data

So before any visualisation always consider:

Discrete & continuous quantities
Categories

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Visualising numerical variables
Sometimes you are interested in the magnitude of some set of numbers.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Visualising numerical variables
We frequently encounter situations where we want to understand how a particular variable is distributed within a dataset. For example, in a sales dataset, we might be interested in examining the distribution of monthly revenue, the number of units sold per product, or the average transaction value. Understanding these distributions helps us identify patterns, spot outliers, and make data-driven decisions for improving business performance.






Walmart Distribution of Sales

Code 1Plot:Item



item_stat <- wal_train |> 
  ggplot(aes(units)) +
  geom_histogram() +
  guides(x = guide_axis(angle = 90)) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Items Sold",
       y = "Item Number",
       x = "Units Sold",
       caption = "Data: Kaggle â€¢ Viz: Ifeoma Egbogah")


















Chart Type
Best For




Line Chart
Trends over time


Bar Chart
Comparing categories


Scatter Plot
Correlations, relationships


Maps
Geospatial data


Dashboard
Monitoring KPIs in real-time



Tip: Choose simplicity and clarity over complexity.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Simple Text

When youâ€™re dealing with just one or two figures, using plain text can often be the most effective way to share them.
To illustrate, the figure below appeared in an April 2014 report by the Pew Research Center focusing on stay-at-home mothers.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Simple Text

In this instance, a straightforward sentence does the job: in 2012, 20% of children had a traditional stay-at-home mother, down from 41% in 1970 or present it visually as below.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Tables


Engage our verbal system â€” we read them like text.
Ideal for scanning rows and columns to compare specific values.
Best for mixed audiences â€” each person can locate their row or column of interest.
Handle multiple units of measure better than graphs (e.g., percentages, currency, counts).
Preserve exact figures for precision-focused communication.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Designing Clear, Effective Tables
Tables That Talk: Making Your Data Shine


The table design should be subtleâ€”donâ€™t let it distract.
Use light borders or white space to separate rows and columns.
Avoid heavy gridlines, bold shading, or intense colours.
Keep fonts clean and consistent; emphasize only what matters (e.g., bold totals or key values).
The goal: data takes center stage, not the formatting.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
section: Tables That Talk: Making Your Data Shine
text:
Tables That Talk: Making Your Data Shine


The table design should be subtleâ€”donâ€™t let it distract.
Use light borders or white space to separate rows and columns.
Avoid heavy gridlines, bold shading, or intense colours.
Keep fonts clean and consistent; emphasize only what matters (e.g., bold totals or key values).
The goal: data takes center stage, not the formatting.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Heatmaps

A heatmap transforms a table of numbers into a visual experience by using color to represent the size or intensity of values. Instead of relying solely on digits, it fills each cell with varying shadesâ€”making patterns, trends, and outliers instantly easier to spot.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
section: Heatmaps: Coloring Your Way to Clarity
text:
Heatmaps: Coloring Your Way to Clarity
A heatmap transforms a table of numbers into a visual experience by using color to represent the size or intensity of values. Instead of relying solely on digits, it fills each cell with varying shadesâ€”making patterns, trends, and outliers instantly easier to spot.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Coloring Your Way to Clarity

Reduces cognitive load by turning numbers into visual cues.
Color intensity helps the eye quickly identify patterns and outliers.
In a heatmap, darker (more saturated) colors indicate higher values.
Makes it faster and easier to spot key data pointsâ€”like the lowest (5) and highest (24) values.
Unlike plain tables, visual cues guide attention to areas of interest without extra mental effort.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Graphs

Unlike tables, graphs tap into our visual perception, allowing us to grasp patterns and insights much faster. A thoughtfully crafted graph often communicates key messages more quickly than even the best-designed table.
There are countless types of graphs. They are typically grouped into four main categories:

points
lines
bars
area charts.

These core graph styles cover a wide range of everyday data visualization needs.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Points
Scatterplot

A scatterplot is a simple yet powerful chart type used to show the relationship between two numerical variables.
Why Scatterplots Matter in Storytelling:

Reveal relationships: Scatterplots help uncover patterns, trends, and correlations that might otherwise remain hidden in raw data.
Spot outliers: Unusual points stand out visually, making it easy to identify exceptions or anomalies worth further investigation.
Show clusters: When data points form groups, it may hint at sub-categories or behaviors within the data.
Support evidence: In data-driven storytelling, scatterplots visually reinforce claims like â€œas X increases, Y decreases.â€

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Colouring Your Way to Clarity


Reduces cognitive load by turning numbers into visual cues.
Color intensity helps the eye quickly identify patterns and outliers.
In a heatmap, darker (more saturated) colors indicate higher values.
Makes it faster and easier to spot key data pointsâ€”like the lowest (5) and highest (24) values.
Unlike plain tables, visual cues guide attention to areas of interest without extra mental effort.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Carbon Majors

To better understand scatterplot we will explore the historical emissions data from Carbon Majors.

Carbon Majors is a database of historical production data from 122 of the worldâ€™s largest oil, gas, coal, and cement producers. This data is used to quantify the direct operational emissions and emissions from the combustion of marketed products that can be attributed to these entities. These entities include:


75 Investor-owned Companies, 36 State-owned Companies, 11 Nation States, 82 Oil Producing Entities, 81 Gas Entities, 49 Coal Entities, 6 Cement Entities


The data spans back to 1854 and contains over 1.42 trillion tonnes of CO2 emissions covering 72% of global fossil fuel and cement emissions since the start of the Industrial Revolution in 1751.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Line Graph

Line graph can show a single series of data, two series of data, or multiple series.
To illustrate we will use data collected by the US gov on all doctoral degree graduates every year. The data comes from the NSF.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Slopegraph

Slopegraph is a hybrid of a line graph and a time series as it only compares two values, connected by a line, with a continuous date axis.
Slopegraphs are powerful visual tools that convey a wealth of information at a glance. Not only do the points show actual values, but the connecting lines instantly reveal upward or downward trendsâ€”visually communicating changes over time. Without needing to define concepts like â€œrate of change,â€ the slope naturally tells the story, making the data intuitive and easy to interpret.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R

What Line Graphs Show:

Trends â€“ Are values increasing, decreasing, or remaining stable?
Fluctuations â€“ Are there spikes or dips over time?
Comparisons â€“ How do different categories or groups evolve across time?

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Points: Small Dots, Big Insights

Point plots use individual dots to represent data values. Simple but powerful, they are excellent for highlighting individual observations or comparing values across categories with precision.
Why Use Point Plots?

Show exact values clearly: Each dot represents a data point, making it easy to compare and spot differences.
Reduce clutter: Point plots can present data more cleanly than bar charts, especially when working with many categories or limited space.
Highlight outliers: Unusual or extreme values stand out visually.

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
text:
Scatterplot

A scatterplot is a simple yet powerful chart type used to show the relationship between two numerical variables.
Why Scatterplots Matter in Storytelling:

Reveal relationships: Scatterplots help uncover patterns, trends, and correlations that might otherwise remain hidden in raw data.
Spot outliers: Unusual points stand out visually, making it easy to identify exceptions or anomalies worth further investigation.
Show clusters: When data points form groups, it may hint at sub-categories or behaviors within the data.
Support evidence: In data-driven storytelling, scatterplots visually reinforce claims like â€œas X increases, Y decreases.â€

title: Bridging Data and Decision-Making: Data Visualization Techniques with R
section: Lines: Connecting the Dots of Change
text:
Lines: Connecting the Dots of Change

A line graph is one of the most effective tools for visualizing how something changes over time. It connects individual data points with a line, allowing us to quickly see trends, shifts, and patterns.
What Line Graphs Show:

Trends â€“ Are values increasing, decreasing, or remaining stable?
Fluctuations â€“ Are there spikes or dips over time?
Comparisons â€“ How do different categories or groups evolve across time?
